questions.text: A 17 year old patient presents with lesions on face. Which of the following is not a causative factor of this disease?
questions.solution:
The disease in the picture is acne vulgaris as comedone, papules are visible on the forehead of this young girl.

There are 4 main factors that contribute to acne

  1. Follicular hyperkeratinization:Increased proliferation of keratinocytes leads to obstruction of the follicle, essentially plugging the pilosebaceous unit
  2. Seborrhoea : stimulation of sebaceous gland secretion by androgens
  3. Propionibacterium acnes within follicle:‘Pacnes,’ is the main bacteria involved in the pathogenesis of acne. It is an anaerobic bacteria that thrives in the lipid-rich environment of sebum. Colonization of P. acnes triggers the immune system and leads to perifollicular inflammation.
  4. inflammation:Acne progression often happens due to inflammation from a small comedo to an inflammatory papule or nodule. Main mediator – IL -1 alpha

choices.text: Androgens are related to the pathogenesis
Obesity and smoking are the 2 main factors associated with it
IL-17 inhibitors like secukinumab can be used in treatment
It is a disease of the sebaceous glands

questions.text: Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS), also called acne inversus, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition with lesions including deep-seated nodules and abscesses, draining tracts, and fibrotic scars. These lesions most commonly occur in intertriginous areas and areas rich in apocrine glands. Among the most common are axillary, groin, perianal, perineal, and inframammary locations.

Environmental and behavioral factors also contribute. Individuals with HS are more commonly overweight or obese. Obesity leads to greater intertriginous surface area and skin friction, increased sweat production and retention, and hormonal changes leading to relative androgen excess, all of which are associated with HS. Metabolic syndrome is more common in obese individuals and thus is also seen more commonly in HS.

Smoking is also prevalent among those diagnosed with HS. Causation is unclear; however, nicotine may cause increased follicular plugging. As with obesity; disease progression and severity are worse in those who smoke.

The influence of hormones can be seen in HS. There is a greater prevalance in females than males, with the age of primary occurance most commonly between puberty and menopause. In addition, there are fluctuations of occurance and severity with menstrual cycles and exogenous hormones.

questions.text: A 21 year old patient with history of anxiety disorder presents with lesions as shown in the picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acne Excoriée is an excoriation disorder in whichpatients have a conscious, repetitive, and uncontrollable desire to pick, scratch, or rub acne lesions. Excoriation disorders are a distinct entity within the group of Obsessive-Compulsive (OCD) and Related Disorders.

Lesions vary in size (millimeters to several centimeters), shape (linear/angular to circular/oval) and are grouped along sites of the body that are easily accessible and usually exposed. Ultimately, the repeated picking results in erosions, ulcerations, and long-term scarring with hyper or hypopigmentation When treating a patient with acne excoriée, it is important to first identify any underlying psychological disorder that could account for skin picking behavior. Since Obsessive–Compulsive Disorders are associated with serotonin mediated neural pathways, SSRIs can be helpful Cognitive behavioral therapy, habit reversal therapy, and acceptance enhanced behavior, have also been reported to reduce skin picking

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrect about the disease shown in the picture?

1. Dihydrotestosterone is responsible for follicular miniaturisation
2. Aro-perkins bodies are seen within the follicular stelae
3. Minoxidil 2% is used in the treatment
4. Finasteride acts as a selective antagonist of androgen receptor
questions.solution:
Androgenetic alopecia is a genetically predetermined disorder due to an excessive response to androgens. Characterized by progressive loss of terminal hair of the scalp any time after puberty.

It follows a characteristic distribution in both males and females. In males, hair loss is most prominent in the vertex and frontotemporal regions, while in women the frontal hairline is typically spared with diffuse hair loss at the crown and top of head, with loss often marked by a wider center part.

Also called as patterned hair loss In androgenetic alopecia, excessive activation leads to follicular miniaturization through a progressively shorter anagen phase, resulting in thinner and shorter hair follicles

Androgenetic alopecia patients have higher production of dihydrotestosterone, and higher levels of 5 alpha-reductase and androgen receptors in balding scalp.

Type 1 5 alpha-reductase enzymes are in sebaceous glands, keratinocytes, and sweat glands. Type 2 5 alpha-reductase enzymes are in the outer root sheath of hair follicles, epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles, and prostate.

There are two FDA approved drugs for pattern baldness: topical minoxidil and finasteride. Topical minoxidil is approved in 5% concentration for MPHL and 2% concentration for FPHL. Finasteride is a 5 alpha-reductase type 2 inhibitor and not an anti-androgen.

questions.text: A patient with hyperpigmented warty papules on the face and neck presents with nail findings as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Keratosis follicularis, also known as Darier disease (DD)autosomal dominantly inherited genodermatosis Mutations in the geneATP2A2

The lesions may first appear as skin-colored or yellow-brown papules with a greasy, warty texture. These lesions are especially common in seborrheic areas such as the forehead, scalp, margin of the scalp, nasolabial folds, ears, chest, and back Nail changes in keratosis follicularis (Darier disease) provide important diagnostic clues. A sandwich of red and white longitudinal bands, often with a V-shaped nick at the free margin of the nail, is the most pathognomonic nail finding

questions.text: This is associated with which syndrome?
questions.solution:
Gardner syndrome, a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis(FAP)is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by GI polyps, multiple osteomas, and skin and soft tissue tumors. Cutaneous findings[2]of Gardner syndrome include epidermoid cysts, desmoid tumors, and other benign tumors. Polyps have a 100% risk of undergoing malignant transformation

genetically linked to band 5q21, the adenomatous polyposis coli locus

Cowden syndrome

CS is associated with a predisposition for developing both benign and malignant internal tumours.autosomal dominant multisystem disease germline mutation in thePTENtumour suppressor gene in chromosome 10.

Malignancy -breast cancer, Thyroid malignancy, endometrial carcinoma

Cutaneous features in CS include trichilemmomas, acral keratosis, Angiolipomas, Oral mucosal papillomas and fibromas

Muir-Torre syndrome –autosomal dominant genodermatosis germline mutation in the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes Over 90% of cases are found to have mutations in the MSH2 gene

Diagnostic criteria include the presence of at least one sebaceous neoplasm together with an internal malignancy or the presence of multiple keratoacanthomas and an internal malignancy in a patient with a family history of MTS

MTS has a strong association with colorectal, uterine and ovarian adenocarcinoma; other gastrointestinal malignancies and transitional cancers of the renal tract can also occur.

Muir-Torre syndrome (MTS) is associated with characteristic cutaneous features, including the development of sebaceous gland neoplasms (Sebaceous adenoma Sebaceous epithelioma Sebaceous carcinoma) and keratoacanthomas

Gorlin Syndrome

  • Synonym: Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Underlying cause: Germline mutation of PTCI, a tumor suppressing gene
  • Features: Genodermatoses with Basal cell carcinomas and Multiorgan abnormalities

questions.text: A 8 year old boy presented with patch of partial alopecia with broken hair and easy pluckability of hair. The disease is not caused by:
questions.solution:
• Causative agent of Dermatophytic infections: Keratinophilic fungi
  • Trichophyton
  • Microsporum
  • Epidermophyton

Tinea capitis is caused by dermatophytes of Tricho-phyton and Microsporum species only

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient on cancer chemotherapy presented with severe diffuse hair fall for last 1 month. She started her cancer chemotherapy 2 months back. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Anagen effluvium is a form of nonscarring alopecia commonly associated with chemotherapy In this disorder, affected anagen hairs suffer a toxic or inflammatory insult, resulting in fracture of the hair shaft. Shedding usually takes place within 14 days of administration of the offending drug it is reversible, with hair regrowth growth upon discontinuation of the offending agent.

questions.text:
Bamboo hair as shown in the image below is seen in _____:
< img class = "w-100" style="height:auto;display:block;vertical-align: middle;border:0;"src="https://d1mobye7msb5bl.cloudfront.net/QuizOct2021/Dermatology02102021/9Q.jpg">
questions.solution:
Netherton syndromeis a severe, autosomal recessive form of SPINK5gene

Patients with this disorder tend to have a hair shaft defect

The disrupted skin barrier function in affected individuals also presents a high susceptibility to infection and allergy, leading to the development of scaly, reddish skin similar to atopic dermatitis In some cases, may also see milde ichthyosis linearis circumflexa

questions.text: Identify the nail condition shown in the below Image:
questions.solution: The image shows Trachyonychia, also called sandpapered nails which is a condition characterized by rough accentuated linear ridges(longitudinal striations) on the nails of the fingers and toes. The condition is called twenty-nail dystrophy, when it involves all the twenty nails of the fingers and toes. It may present as an idiopathic disorder of the nails or it can be associated with other dermatological conditions. Alopecia areata(AA) is the most common disease in patients with Trachyonychia. Trachyonychia is also seen in ~10% of patients affected by nail lichen planus(LP). It is also associated with other conditions such as psoriasis, immunoglobulin A deficiency, atopic dermatitis, and ichthyosis vulgaris. Self limiting condition

questions.text: The image below represents:
questions.solution: Fordyce's spot represents ectopic sebaceous glands on lips (most common site) and oral mucosa. They may also appear on vulva and penis, they are not associated with hair follicles (In contrast to normal sebaceous glands which have their ducts in hair follicles). Fordyce's spot is totally benign condition which occurs in normal people. It is characterized by discrete, pin-head sized superficial, light or yellow milium-like, maculo-papular lesions in mucous membrane of lips (especially vermilion portion), and sometimes buccal mucosa. The condition usually appears at puberty and is more common in males. Fordyce's spots are often confused with koplik's spot of measles ~ There is erythmatous halo around the Koplik's spot which is not there in Fordyce's spot As the condition is asymptomatic, no treatment is required, other than reassurance

questions.text: A 24-year-old unmarried woman presents with lesions on face, upper back and shoulders for 2 years. The drug of choice for her treatment.
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin

It is used to treat the most severe form of acne (nodular acne)

Female patients must not get pregnant:
For 1 month before starting isotretinoin, while takin isotretinoin
For 1 month after stopping isotretinoin

E. Acitretin

It is used in pustular psoriasis

questions.text: Patient with pre-existing acne lesions was treated with long term antibiotics(tetracyclines). Developed papulo-pustules or nodules around nose and lips. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
caused by gram-negative organisms. The infection may occur as a complication in patients with acne vulgaris, who have received systemic antibiotics for prolonged periods

Gram-negative folliculitis should be considered in patients with acne who have a flare-up of pustular or cystic lesions

Isotretinoin offers the most effective cure for gram-negative folliculitis

questions.text: The most likely diagnosis in the Image shown?
questions.solution: Acne keloidalis nuchae (AKN) is a chronic inflammatory condition that leads to scarring of the hair follicles, development of keloid-like papules and plaques, and scarring alopecia on the nape of the neck and occipital scallop. This condition most commonly occurs in blacks, AKN can also be seen in Caucasians. Moreover, the condition has a predilection for men, occurring 20 times more frequently than in women, and starts after adolescence. The natural course of disease starts with the early formation of inflamed papules with marked erythema. Secondary infection can lead to pustules and abscess formation in some cases. Over time, continued inflammation leads to pronounced fibrosis and keloid formation with coalescence of the papules into large plaques and nodules. Later stages of presentation include chronic scarring and/or scarring alopecia without active inflammation. Histologically, there is inflammation, fibroplasias, and disappearance of sebaceous glands.

questions.text: SAPHO Syndrome components are all except:
questions.solution:
Acronym for the combination of Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, Hyperostosis, and Osteitis

  • Chronic disorder that involves the skin, bone, and joints
  • Some researchers feel that the SAPHO syndrome is related to the group of arthritis conditions which typically affect the spine, called Spondyloarthropathies
  • Treatment typically involves medications which reduce inflammation

questions.text: a 20 year old girl presents with lesions in the axilla. All are true about this except
questions.solution: Fox Fordyce disease is due to chronic blockade of apocrine sweat gland ducts, with a secondary, non-bacterial inflammatory response to the secretions and cellular debris in cyst. It is more common in women aged 13-35 years. Axilla is the most common site of involvement. Periareolar, inframammary and pubic areas can also be involved

questions.text:
A 25 year old boy presented with excessive sweating of both hands and feet, causing a lot of disturbance to his daily activities. Which of the following treatments can be used?
1.Pilocarpine solution
2.Timolol solution
3.Iontophoresis
4.Botulinum toxin injection
5.20% aluminum chloride solution
questions.solution:
Hyperhidrosis is excessive sweating beyond what is physiologically required for thermoregulation, often causing social, emotional, and work impairment. This condition can be primary or secondary. Primary hyperhidrosis is idiopathic, bilaterally symmetric, excessive sweating of the axillae, palms, soles, face, and, less commonly, scalp or inguinal folds. Secondary hyperhidrosis may be focal or generalized, and is caused by an underlying medical condition or medication use

First-line treatment of all primary focal hyperhidrosis, regardless of severity, is topical 20% aluminum chloride For craniofacial hyperhidrosis, topical 2% glycopyrrolate (compounded by a pharmacy) may be considered first-line treatment.

For palmar and plantar hyperhidrosis, iontophoresis may be effective as first- or second-line treatment. Iontophoresis is the passing of an ionized substance, usually water, through the skin by the application of a direct electrical current. Its mechanism of action is unknown

Botulinum toxin injection is the most studied hyperhidrosis treatment and demonstrates consistent improvementin the axillae and palms Botulinum toxins bind synaptic proteins, blocking the release of acetylcholine from the cholinergic neurons that innervate the eccrine sweat glands oral anticholinergics for treating primary hyperhidrosis

questions.text: a teenage boy presents with patchy non scarring hairloss. The examination findings on dermoscopy are shown below. What is the type of this disorder.
questions.solution:
Trichotillomania(TTM), also known ashair pulling disorderorcompulsive hair pulling, is a psychiatric disorder characterized by a long-term urge that results in the pulling out of one's hair.

Classified as obsessive compulsive disorder.

The scalp is the most common pulling site, followed by the eyebrows, eyelashes, face, arms, and legIndividuals with trichotillomania exhibit hair of differing lengths; some are broken hairs with blunt ends, some new growth with tapered ends, some broken mid-shaft,

Scaling on the scalp is not present, overall hair density is normal, and a hair pull test is negative (the hair does not pull out easily).

Dermoscopy findings: Common trichoscopic feature - decreased hair density and broken hairs. Trichoptilosis('split ends'), flame hair, v-sign, perifollicular hemorrhages.

The subset of individuals with TTM who ingest the hairs after puling are at risk of gastrointestinal complications stemming from trichobezoars (i.e., hairballs)

questions.text: a 7 day old neonate wrapped up in multiple layers of clothing presented with clinical picture as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Miliaria crystallina appears as 1 to 2 mm superficial vesicles, affecting both adults and neonates usually younger than 2 weeks old. Since the pathophysiology involves the most superficial layer of the epidermis, the stratum corneum, the vesicles have a thin superficial layer. This results in the vesicles resembling water droplets on the skin that easily rupture. he vesicles are superficial; therefore, an inflammatory response is typically absent. The upper trunk, neck, and head are the most commonly affected sites. The rash will usually appear within a few days of exposure to risk factors and will resolve within a day after the superficial layer of skin rubs off.

questions.text: what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Syringomasare benign eccrine sweat duct tumors, typically found clustered on eyelids,

They are skin-colored or yellowish polygonal, translucent papules,1–3mm in diameter, While they can present at any time in life, they typically present during adolescence. They are usually not associated with any other symptoms
